title: 109_hr5178
content: There is a section dedicated to the study. The Secretary of Homeland Security and the Director of National Intelligence will conduct a study on best practices for communication of terrorist threat information among government entities, focusing on Joint Terrorism Task Forces and State Homeland Security Fusion Centers. The study will examine coordination methods among Federal, State, and local entities for sharing counter-terrorism information. The study will focus on coordinating activities among Federal, State, and local entities in responding to terrorist threats, including communication to the public. The Secretary may obtain necessary information from US departments or agencies, handling classified information appropriately. The Secretary may also request temporary duty of Federal personnel. The Secretary, in conjunction with the Director, may request personnel from US departments or agencies for temporary duty without loss of seniority, pay, or other employee status. A report containing findings, conclusions, best practices, and recommendations for information processing must be submitted to Congress within 6 months of the Act's enactment. Recommendations for a formalized process of consultation, communication, and confidentiality between Federal, State, and local governments to facilitate communication and prevent unauthorized dissemination of information regarding terrorist threats. The Secretary may submit a portion of the report in classified form if deemed appropriate. $5,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2007 to carry out this section. SEC. 2. CENTERS OF BEST PRACTICES. The Secretary of Homeland Security, with the Director of National Intelligence, will establish 3 Centers in New York City, Detroit, and Los Angeles to implement best practices for processing terrorist threat information. The Center will be located in Los Angeles and will implement best practices for information sharing on terrorist threats, coordinate with other metropolitan areas, develop training curriculum, provide funding and technical assistance, and establish a method to advertise these practices. Authorization of Appropriations: $10,000,000 for fiscal year 2007 and $3,000,000 for each fiscal year from 2008 to 2012 for the Centers. Report to Congress by March 31, 2010, evaluating operations and recommending future funding.
